elements.content: A new functionalized 1,2,4-triazole ligand, 4-[(E)-2-(5-methyl-2-thienyl)­vinyl]-1,2,4-triazole (thiome), was prepared to assess the broad applicability of strategically producing multistep spin transitions in two-dimensional Hofmann-type materials of the type [FeIIPd­(CN)4(R-1,2,4-trz)2]·nH2O (R-1,2,4-trz = a 4-functionalized 1,2,4-triazole ligand). A variety of structural and magnetic investigations on the resultant framework material [FeIIPd­(CN)4(thiome)2]·2H2O (A·2H 2 O) reveal that a high-spin (HS) to low-spin (LS) transition is inhibited in A·2H 2 O due to a combination of guest and ligand steric bulk effects. The water molecules can be reversibly removed with retention of the porous host framework and result in the emergence of an abrupt and hysteretic one-step spin transition due to the removal of guest internal pressure. A spin transition can, furthermore, be induced in A·2H 2 O (0–0.68 GPa) under hydrostatic pressure, as evidenced by variable-pressure structure and magnetic studies, resulting in a two-step spin transition at ambient temperatures at 0.68 GPa. The presence of a two-step spin crossover (SCO) in A·2H 2 O under hydrostatic pressure compared to a one-step SCO in A at ambient pressure is discussed in terms of the relative ability of each phase to accommodate mixed HS/LS states according to differing lattice flexibilities.

elements.content: Solvent molecule steric bulk has been shown to deactivate spin-state switching in a porous two-dimensional Hofmann material. The process of guest removal or the application of external pressure each results in the activation of cooperative spin-transition behaviors.
elements.clean_text: Solvent molecule steric bulk has been shown to deactivate spin-state switching in a porous two-dimensional Hofmann material. The process of guest removal or the application of external pressure each results in the activation of cooperative spin-transition behaviors.

elements.content: Spin crossover (SCO) is an electronic switching phenomenon that can occur in d4–7 transition-metal complexes of appropriate intermediate ligand-field strength under external perturbation (T, P, and hν). It is well established that the total ligand field imparted on such metal ions is comprised of both inner- and outer- coordination-sphere characteristics (i.e., hydrogen bonding and p–p stacking). Effective propagation of spin-state changes in a solid (i.e., cooperativity in SCO materials) is governed primarily by elastic interactions between the switchable metal ions. Increasing strength and cooperativity of elastic interactions between SCO centers has the tendency to sharpen the spin transition from broad to abrupt and lead commonly to the observation of thermal hysteresis. The incorporation of SCO centers into coordination polymers is a strategy anticipated to increase the strength of interactions between metal ions and has been largely successful when short bridges are employed, for example, in one-dimensional chain species of the type [FeII(R-trz)3]­(A)2·nH2O (where R-trz = a 1,2,4-triazole-type ligand and A = anion) and the family of Hofmann materials [FeIIMII(CN)4(L)]·n(guest) [where MII = Pt, Pd, and Ni and L = bis­(4-pyridyl) bridging ligand]. In both of these families, examples of room temperature and cooperative spin transitions exist.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Spin crossover (SCO) is an electronic switching phenomenon that can occur in d4-7 transition-metal complexes of appropriate intermediate ligand-field strength under external perturbation (T, P, and  hν). It is well established that the total ligand field imparted on such metal ions is comprised of both inner- and outer- coordination-sphere characteristics (i.e., hydrogen bonding and p-p stacking). Effective propagation of spin-state changes in a solid (i.e., cooperativity in SCO materials) is governed primarily by elastic interactions between the switchable metal ions. Increasing strength and cooperativity of elastic interactions between SCO centers has the tendency to sharpen the spin transition from broad to abrupt and lead commonly to the observation of thermal hysteresis. The incorporation of SCO centers into coordination polymers is a strategy anticipated to increase the strength of interactions between metal ions and has been largely successful when short bridges are employed, for example, in one-dimensional chain species of the type [FeII(R-trz)3](A)2⋅nH2O (where R-trz = a 1,2,4-triazole-type ligand and A = anion) and the family of Hofmann materials [FeIIMII(CN)4(L)]⋅n(guest) [where MII = Pt, Pd, and Ni and L = bis(4-pyridyl) bridging ligand]. In both of these families, examples of room temperature and cooperative spin transitions exist.

elements.content: Alongside the intrinsic lattice cooperativity of the Hofmann family of SCO materials, the pillared layered topology with interlayer pore space allows for rational tuning of the SCO properties through the strategic incorporation of a range of potential hydrogen-bonding and π-stacking interaction sites within the framework scaffold. These systems are of fundamental interest because their robust nature allows direct magnetostructural rationalization in terms of a simple guest size/shape argument (“internal pressure”) and guest electronic effects. While the majority of Hofmann materials reported are based on pyridyl donor ligands, we showed previously that the incorporation of 1,2,4-triazole-type ligands [bound through N(1)] into two-dimensional (2D) Hofmann-type materials is of interest, particularly because it provides a unique approach for generating layer distortions and multistability. For example, [FeIIPd­(CN)4(thtrz)2]·(EtOH,H2O) (thtrz = N-thiophenylidene-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-amine) shows a two-step SCO character with an unusually wide intermediate-spin-state temperature plateau (120 K). This unusual high-spin (HS)/low-spin (LS) state thermal stability is provided by a range of antagonistic hydrogen-bonding interactions and the ability of the Hofmann topology to stabilize the resultant lattice distortion. Here, we explore the broad applicability of this approach by investigating a new 1,2,4-triazole-type ligand. To date, the vast majority of multistep spin transitions are generated serendipitously but may be enabled by this overall approach because of the strategically imbedded range of ferro- and antiferroelastic interactions. Here, we find, through a range of structure and magnetic studies conducted under temperature and hydrostatic pressure variation, that a multistep SCO is evident, but the spin transition is inhibited when guest molecules are present due to internal pressure effects. Indeed, the ca. 10 % volume change necessary for the HS-to-LS transition to proceed is only possible under hydrostatic pressure application or with the removal of guest molecules. Despite many publications dealing with the application of hydrostatic pressure to SCO polymeric materials, few focus on guest-loaded species. We show here that such studies are beneficial for uncovering “hidden” SCO properties but may also be advantageous for revealing new SCO properties because both host–host and host–guest interactions may be perturbed and/or enhanced in synergy.

elements.content:
All reagents were commercially available and were used as received [iron­(II) perchlorate was handled carefully and in small amounts to avoid any potential explosions].

Ligand Synthesis

4-Amino-1,2,4-triazole (1.5 g, 17.5 mmol) and 5-methyl-2-thiophenecarboxaldehyde (2.76 g, 21.9 mmol) were dissolved in 50 mL of ethanol (EtOH) along with 4 drops of concentrated H2SO4. The solution was refluxed and stirred for 5 h. With cooling to room temperature, a white precipitate formed and was washed with cold water (H2O) followed by EtOH. The crude product was recrystallized from EtOH. M w: 192.25. Yield: 1.7 g (51%). 1H NMR (200 MHz, DMSO-d 6, δ/ppm): 9.15 (s, 1H), 9.09 (s, 2H), 7.51 (d, 3 J HH = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 6.98 (d, 3 J HH = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 2.53 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6, δ/ppm): 152.8, 146.9, 138.8, 136.0, 133.9, 127.3, 15.5. ESI-MS: m/z 192.87 (M + H peak), 214.87 (M + Na peak). IR (solid, ν/cm–1): 3108 (s), 2960 (m), 1601 (s), 1508 (s), 1490 (s), 1475 (s), 1452 (m), 1379 (m), 1295 (m), 1247 (m), 1220 (m), 1205 (m), 1164 (s), 1058 (s), 1048 (s), 975 (m), 838 (m), 806 (s), 621 (m), 573 (s), 545 (m), 518 (m), 485 (m). Microanalysis. Calcd for C8H8N4S: C, 49.98; H, 4.19; N, 29.15. Found: C, 49.94; H, 4.24; N, 29.21.

elements.content: Crystals were grown by vial-in-vial slow diffusion. Powders of thiome (22.7 mg, 0.118 mmol) and K2[Pd­(CN)4] (17.0 mg, 0.0589 mmol) were placed at the base of a small vial. Fe­(ClO4)2·6H2O (15.0 mg, 0.0589 mmol) was placed at the base of a large vial. The small vial was placed inside the large vial, and both were slowly filled with a 50:50 EtOH/H2O mixture, being careful to fill the vials without disturbing the reactants. The components were allowed to diffuse over a period of 2 weeks to form yellow crystals. IR (cm–1; A·2H 2 O): 3381 (br), 2171 (s), 1632 (s), 1591 (s), 1515 (s), 1474 (m), 1459 (s), 1328 (m), 1302 (m), 1256 (m), 1221 (m), 1172 (m), 1161 (m), 1052 (s), 964 (m), 854 (m), 815 (m), 619 (s), 546 (m), 513 (m), 497 (m), 410 (s). IR (cm–1, A): 417 (s), 489 (m), 510 (m), 548 (m), 616 (s), 811 (s), 858 (m), 938 (m), 1050 (s), 1166 (m), 1219 (m), 1460 (m), 1509 (s), 1593 (s), 1619 (m), 2174 (s). Microanalysis. Calcd for C20H16N12S2 (A·2H 2 O): C, 34.97; H, 2.35; N, 24.48. Found: C, 34.84; H, 2.58; N, 24.35.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on A·2H 2 O at 200 K. In situ removal of guest H2O molecules was carried out on a single crystal heated to 375 K, which was mounted on a loop without the use of oil to ensure that guest molecules could escape. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on A at 375, 200, and 100 K. All single-crystal data were collected using a Bruker APEX2 diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode (λ = 0.7017 Å), and data integration and reduction were performed using the Bruker software suite. Structural solution for all materials was completed within SHELXS-97 and refined using SHELXL-97 within the X-SEED user interface. All atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed using the riding model. Further structural analysis details and thermal ellipsoid diagrams (ORTEP 50% probability) are presented in Figures S3–S5. The single-crystal structural refinement parameters and structural details are summarized in , and selected bond lengths and angles and other parameters are listed in . CCDC 1480120–1480123 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for A at 100, 230, and 375 K and A·2H 2 O at 200 K, respectively. These data are provided free of charge by The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on A⋅2H  2  O at 200 K. In situ removal of guest H2O molecules was carried out on a single crystal heated to 375 K, which was mounted on a loop without the use of oil to ensure that guest molecules could escape. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on A at 375, 200, and 100 K. All single-crystal data were collected using a Bruker APEX2 diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode (λ = 0.7017 Å), and data integration and reduction were performed using the Bruker software suite. Structural solution for all materials was completed within SHELXS-97 and refined using SHELXL-97  within the X-SEED user interface. All atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed using the riding model. Further structural analysis details and thermal ellipsoid diagrams (ORTEP 50% probability) are presented in Figures S3-S5. The single-crystal structural refinement parameters and structural details are summarized in , and selected bond lengths and angles and other parameters are listed in . CCDC 1480120-1480123 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for A at 100, 230, and 375 K and A⋅2H  2  O at 200 K, respectively. These data are provided free of charge by The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre.

A sample of A·2H 2 O was heated from room temperature to 600 °C at a rate of 1 °C min–1 under a dry nitrogen gas flow (20 mL min–1) using a TA Instruments Discovery thermogravimetric analyzer.

Gravimetric Analysis

A H2O sorption isotherm was obtained on a Hiden-Isochema intelligent gravimetric analyzer. Prior to adsorption, the sample was outgassed under vacuum (10–5 bar) at 100 °C overnight. The sample was cooled to the analysis temperature (25 °C) and the dry mass recorded. The sample chamber was pressurized to a set pressure and allowed to equilibrate for 240 min before moving to the next pressure point.

elements.content: Data for magnetic susceptibility measurements were collected on a Quantum Design Versalab Measurement System with a vibrating sample magnetometer attachment. Measurements were taken continuously under an applied field of 0.3 T over the temperature range 300–50–300 K, at a ramp rate of 2 K min–1. In situ desolvation was carried out to produce A with heating to 375 K for 1.5 h, followed by measurements over the range of 375–50–300 K. A variety of scan rates were applied to the measurements, but only the 2 K min–1 data are presented here because there was no rate dependence.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Susceptibility Measurements

Data for magnetic susceptibility measurements were collected on a Quantum Design Versalab Measurement System with a vibrating sample magnetometer attachment. Measurements were taken continuously under an applied field of 0.3 T over the temperature range 300-50-300 K, at a ramp rate of 2 K min-1. In situ desolvation was carried out to produce A with heating to 375 K for 1.5 h, followed by measurements over the range of 375-50-300 K. A variety of scan rates were applied to the measurements, but only the 2 K min-1 data are presented here because there was no rate dependence.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements under pressure were performed on A·2H 2 O and A using a hydrostatic pressure cell, specially designed for the SQUID setup in the València laboratory (SQUID specifications: Quantum Design MPMS2 SQUID magnetometer operating at 1 T and 1.8–300 K), made of hardened beryllium bronze with silicon oil as the pressure-transmitting medium and operating over the pressure range of 1 bar to 12 kbar. The compound (13 mg) was packed in a cylindrically shaped sample holder (1 mm diameter and 5–7 mm length) made up of very thin aluminum foil. The pressure was calibrated using the transition temperature of superconducting lead of high purity (99.999%).

elements.content: Calorimetric measurements were performed on A by using a differential scanning calorimeter (Mettler Toledo DSC 823e). Measurements were carried out by using ca. 3 mg of the sample sealed in a 40 μL aluminum pan with a mechanical crimp (an empty pan was used as a reference). The sample holder was kept in a drybox under a flow of dry nitrogen gas (50 mL min–1) to avoid H2O condensation. The differential scanning calorimeter was liquid-nitrogen-cooled. Temperature and heat-flow calibrations were made with standard samples of sapphire. Sample desolvation was achieved within the DSC machine by heating a sample of A·2H 2 O to 140 °C. Holes were placed in the lid of the aluminum pan to allow H2O vapor to escape.

elements.content: The X-rays (17.03 keV and 0.72808 Å) available at the 17-BM beamline at the APS at Argonne National Laboratory were used in combination with a PerkinElmer area detector with a carbon window to record diffraction patterns. For variable-temperature measurements, a polycrystalline sample of A·2H 2 O was ground as a slurry and loaded into a quartz capillary (0.7 mm diameter) that was open at one end to enable in situ desolvation. The sample temperature was controlled using an Oxford Cryosystems open-flow cryostream, and the data were collected in 20 s exposures during continuous ramping over the range of 200–375 K for A·2H 2 O and 375–100–200 K for A at 120 K h–1. This corresponds to the collection of diffraction images at 2 K intervals. LaB6 was used as a standard.

elements.content: 4-[(E)-2-(5-Methyl-2-thienyl)­vinyl]-1,2,4-triazole (thiome) was prepared by the same methodology as that of the previously reported analogues. Single crystals of A·2H 2 O were readily prepared via slow diffusion techniques and A by heating to 375 K for >1.5 h. For each, the IR spectra show the strong stretching vibration mode of the cyano groups around 2170 cm–1, consistent with the formation of [FeIIPd­(CN)4] grids. Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that the two guest H2O molecules in A·2H 2 O are removed over the range 100–140 °C to produce the guest vacant framework, A (Figure S1). Gravimetric H2O sorption analyses reveal a very slow uptake of H2O molecules, with the fully hydrated phase being stable to low pressures at ambient temperature (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

4-[(E)-2-(5-Methyl-2-thienyl)vinyl]-1,2,4-triazole (thiome) was prepared by the same methodology as that of the previously reported analogues. Single crystals of A⋅2H  2  O were readily prepared via slow diffusion techniques and A by heating to 375 K for >1.5 h. For each, the IR spectra show the strong stretching vibration mode of the cyano groups around 2170 cm-1, consistent with the formation of [FeIIPd(CN)4] grids. Thermogravimetric analysis reveals that the two guest H2O molecules in A⋅2H  2  O are removed over the range 100-140 °C to produce the guest vacant framework, A (Figure S1). Gravimetric H2O sorption analyses reveal a very slow uptake of H2O molecules, with the fully hydrated phase being stable to low pressures at ambient temperature (Figure S2).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction on the yellow square-plate crystals of A·2H 2 O at 200 K revealed a 2D Hofmann material with H2O-filled pores located in the interlayer spacing (). The asymmetric unit consists of a single iron­(II) site, one thiome ligand (a) bound through the N(1) position of the 1,2,4-triazole ring, a [Pd­(CN)4] unit bound through the cyanido nitrogen groups, and a single H2O molecule (b). The average Fe–N bond lengths are ca. 2.2 Å, indicative of iron­(II) in the HS state (). Typical Hofmann-type square grid layers of the type [FeIIPd­(CN)4] result from the bridging of iron­(II) sites by four-connecting [Pd­(CN)4] anions (ab plane; c). The octahedral coordination of iron­(II) sites is completed by axially bound thiome ligands, which protrude above and below each [FeIIPd­(CN)4] layer to form an overall 2D layer topology (d). The near-planarity of these Hofmann layers is highlighted by the idealized Fe–NC angles of near 180° ().
elements.clean_text:
Structure and Magnetic Properties of A⋅2H2O 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction on the yellow square-plate crystals of A⋅2H  2  O at 200 K revealed a 2D Hofmann material with H2O-filled pores located in the interlayer spacing (). The asymmetric unit consists of a single iron(II) site, one thiome ligand (a) bound through the N(1) position of the 1,2,4-triazole ring, a [Pd(CN)4] unit bound through the cyanido nitrogen groups, and a single H2O molecule (b). The average Fe-N bond lengths are ca. 2.2 Å, indicative of iron(II) in the HS state (). Typical Hofmann-type square grid layers of the type [FeIIPd(CN)4] result from the bridging of iron(II) sites by four-connecting [Pd(CN)4] anions (ab plane; c). The octahedral coordination of iron(II) sites is completed by axially bound thiome ligands, which protrude above and below each [FeIIPd(CN)4] layer to form an overall 2D layer topology (d). The near-planarity of these Hofmann layers is highlighted by the idealized Fe-NC angles of near 180° ().

(c) square planar [FeIIPd­(CN)4] Hofmann-type layer viewed down the c-axis (thiome ligands removed for clarity) and (d) one 2D layer of A·2H 2 O. Two adjacent 2D layers of A·2H 2 O viewed along the (e) b-axis and (f) a-axis, highlighting the range of intermolecular interactions.

elements.content: The layers pack efficiently along the c direction with an almost complete head-to-tail overlap between thiome ligands of adjacent layers; the latter form weak π-stacking interactions along the a axis (e). The unbound nitrogen atoms of the 1,2,4-triazole rings are located in a trans orientation across each iron­(II) site, and the thiophene sulfur groups of each ligand are also trans with respect to this unbound nitrogen atom. Thus, within the interlayer spacing, there are small voids lined with hydrogen-bond donor groups from both the unbound triazole nitrogen and thiophene sulfur atoms. Indeed, the sulfur atoms form contacts with adjacent thiome ligands along the b direction and the N(2) triazole atoms form hydrogen-bonding interactions with guest H2O molecules, as illustrated in f.

Thus, within the interlayer spacing, there are small voids lined with hydrogen-bond donor groups from both the unbound triazole nitrogen and thiophene sulfur atoms. Indeed, the sulfur atoms form contacts with adjacent thiome ligands along the b direction and the N(2) triazole atoms form hydrogen-bonding interactions with guest H2O molecules, as illustrated in f.

elements.content: In a comparison of this overall structure with the previously reported analogue [FeIIPd­(CN)4(thtrz)2]·(EtOH,H2O), the most notable difference is that the layers are planar in A·2H 2 O rather than undulating. In [FeIIPd­(CN)4(thtrz)2]·(EtOH,H2O), the layer undulation results in pairs of interacting ligands within each layer spaced by large solvent-filled pores. Here, all of the ligands are equally spaced and do not show any interactions within each layer. Furthermore, there are H2O molecules present in each ligand spacing along the b direction in A·2H 2 O rather than in an alternating arrangement in [FeIIPd­(CN)4(thtrz)2]·(EtOH,H2O). These structural differences likely arise because of the presence of the methyl group positioned in the pores in A·2H 2 O, which keep the adjacent ligands from forming complementary interactions and therefore driving layer distortions. Furthermore, the presence of these bulky substituent alongside the H2O molecules likely restricts the ca. 10% volume contraction necessary for a HS-to-LS transition to occur. Investigations of the structure and magnetic consequence of guest removal were thus conducted to assess this “internal guest pressure” argument for the lack of SCO in A·2H 2 O.

In [FeIIPd(CN)4(thtrz)2]⋅(EtOH,H2O), the layer undulation results in pairs of interacting ligands within each layer spaced by large solvent-filled pores. Here, all of the ligands are equally spaced and do not show any interactions within each layer. elements.content: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements on a bulk crystalline sample of A reveal the emergence of an abrupt and hysteretic one-step SCO (). With cooling from 300 K, the χM T values remain constant at 3.4 cm K mol–1, consistent with HS iron­(II) sites until 185 K, where there is an abrupt drop in the χM T values to 0.2 cm K mol–1 indicative of LS iron­(II) sites. Below 165 K, the χM T values remain constant at 0.2 cm K mol–1. With heating, the same one-step behavior is observed with a hysteresis loop of 20 K (T 1/2↓ = 184 K; T 1/2↑ = 204 K). A DSC measurement was also carried out on A in the 120–300 K temperature range, and the critical temperatures obtained from the exothermic (T 1/2↓ = 183 K) and endothermic (T 1/2↑ = 206 K) curves are in good agreement with the magnetic data (Figure S6).
elements.clean_text:
Dehydrated (A) Magnetic Properties and Structure

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements on a bulk crystalline sample of A reveal the emergence of an abrupt and hysteretic one-step SCO (). With cooling from 300 K, the χM T values remain constant at 3.4 cm K mol-1, consistent with HS iron(II) sites until 185 K, where there is an abrupt drop in the χM T values to 0.2 cm K mol-1 indicative of LS iron(II) sites. Below 165 K, the χM T values remain constant at 0.2 cm K mol-1. With heating, the same one-step behavior is observed with a hysteresis loop of 20 K (T 1/2↓ = 184 K; T 1/2↑ = 204 K). A DSC measurement was also carried out on A in the 120-300 K temperature range, and the critical temperatures obtained from the exothermic (T 1/2↓ = 183 K) and endothermic (T 1/2↑ = 206 K) curves are in good agreement with the magnetic data (Figure S6).

elements.content: Structural characterization of the dehydrated phase was performed in situ by heating a single crystal to 375 K and also by powder X-ray diffraction. There was no loss in the diffraction intensity or crystallinity with guest removal. The achievement of such robustness is relatively uncommon in 2D materials, being more prevalent in three-dimensional (3D) framework materials, and exemplifies the pseudo 3D nature imparted by the network of intermolecular interactions. The crystal symmetry and lattice parameters of the dehydrated phase remain unchanged compared to those of A·2H 2 O, with slight thermal expansion at 375 K (). Single-crystal analysis at 375 K confirms retention of the Hofmann 2D topology and host–host interactions compared to A·2H 2 O ().

elements.content: As an initial overview of the magnetostructural behavior of A over the spin-transition temperature range, variable-temperature synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction studies were carried out on a bulk crystalline sample. Plotting the peak position evolution versus temperature clearly indicates a single-phase behavior over this abrupt SCO profile, where discontinuous (first-order) shifts in the Bragg peaks occur at the temperatures of a HS ↔ LS transition (a). While there is a cooperative shift between the two spin states within the sample, there is a small temperature interval (<5 K) where both the HS and LS states coexist. Le Bail refinement of individual powder X-ray diffraction patterns reveals the overall volume changes via normal thermal contraction over the region of 375–170 K and more significantly over the thermal SCO region, with the temperatures of spin transition coincident with magnetic susceptibility measurements. The cell volume change over the thermal SCO regime of 6.5% is consistent with a complete HS-to-LS transition (b).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction of A was thus carried out at 200 and 100 K, representative of the HS and LS iron­(II) states, respectively (). As observed for the bulk sample via powder X-ray diffraction measurements, the crystal symmetry remains unchanged over the spin transition and a contraction consistent with SCO is observed from 200 to 100 K. A direct comparison between the 200 K hydrated and 230 K dehydrated HS phases reveals no change in the 2D Hofmann-type topology and negligible variation to internal interactions or average Fe–N bond lengths. Most notably, the S···S contacts between thiome ligands within adjacent layers are longer in the desolvated material than in the solvated material. Further, the degree of octahedral distortion of the iron­(II) sites between the solvated and desolvated phases in the HS state is unchanged, where we might expect that the desolvated phase allows a more regular octahedron due to there being fewer host–guest internal pressure constraints and vacant pore space. This in itself is an indication that the difference in the magnetic response results from internal pressure inhibition effects imparted by the H2O molecules. In particular, a complete HS-to-LS transition is accompanied by a ca. 10% volume reduction, which in this case impacts both the lattice and enclosed pores. This requires more dense packing within the pores. Accordingly, guests can affect the resistance to SCO. Considering the electrostatic outer-coordination-sphere influence of the H2O···triazole hydrogen-bonding interaction, the solvate molecules would donate electron density to the iron­(II) centers, and their subsequent absence should decrease the ligand-field splitting at the iron­(II) centers, effectively stabilizing the HS state and, thus, further substantiating a chemical pressure argument.

elements.content: In view of the absence of a spin transition in A·2H 2 O compared to the abrupt and hysteretic transition that occurs with guest removal, which we attribute to guest-related internal pressure effects, we investigated whether a spin transition in the hydrated phase could be induced under hydrostatic pressure; both the structural and magnetic behaviors were probed. Furthermore, we anticipated at the outset of this study, as has been observed in all 2D Hofmann material systems containing 1,2,4-triazole coordinating ligands reported to date, that a multistep spin transition would be imparted by this general structural platform, which may be “hidden” by the SCO inactivity of the guest-loaded phase but could be revealed under external pressure measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Pressure-Induced Structure and Magnetic Properties of A⋅2H2O 

In view of the absence of a spin transition in A⋅2H  2  O compared to the abrupt and hysteretic transition that occurs with guest removal, which we attribute to guest-related internal pressure effects, we investigated whether a spin transition in the hydrated phase could be induced under hydrostatic pressure; both the structural and magnetic behaviors were probed. Furthermore, we anticipated at the outset of this study, as has been observed in all 2D Hofmann material systems containing 1,2,4-triazole coordinating ligands reported to date, that a multistep spin transition would be imparted by this general structural platform, which may be "hidden" by the SCO inactivity of the guest-loaded phase but could be revealed under external pressure measurements.

elements.content:
Variable-pressure synchrotron powder X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out at ambient temperature on a crystalline sample of A·2H 2 O from ambient pressure up to 2.9 GPa.

The crystallinity of the framework is retained across this pressure range, with no evidence for a crystallographic phase transition below 2.9 GPa (a). Le Bail refinement of individual powder X-ray diffraction patterns allowed determination of the unit cell volume and parameters of A·2H 2 O as a function of the pressure (b and S9).

elements.content: Overall, there are three distinct regimes, characterized by distinct compressibility (). At ambient pressure, we know from the structure and magnetic data that the iron­(II) sites are in the HS state. With pressurization to 0.68 GPa, the peaks shift moderately and the cell volume decrease is consistent with normal pressure-induced compression of a solid of this type (ΔV = 3%). The pressure-induced lattice contraction over this low-pressure region (0–0.68 GPa) was best modeled with a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state with a bulk modulus [K = 1/b = −V(∂P/∂V)] of 12.9(7) GPa. This is comparable with other framework materials such as ZIF-8 and Zn­(CN)2. Pressurization between 0.68 and 0.87 GPa produces a more pronounced but continuous (second-order transition) shift in the diffraction peaks (ΔV = 8.2%). This compressibility is consistent with a pressure-induced SCO event (HS to LS). Above 0.87 GPa, the iron­(II) sites are in the LS state and normal pressure-induced compression is evident. The bulk modulus of this region [K = 58(1) GPa] is also modeled with a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state. Thus, the LS material is less compressible than the HS material at ambient pressure. It is often the case that the high-pressure phases are less compressible.
elements.clean_text: Overall, there are three distinct regimes, characterized by distinct compressibility (). At ambient pressure, we know from the structure and magnetic data that the iron(II) sites are in the HS state. With pressurization to 0.68 GPa, the peaks shift moderately and the cell volume decrease is consistent with normal pressure-induced compression of a solid of this type (ΔV = 3%). The pressure-induced lattice contraction over this low-pressure region (0-0.68 GPa) was best modeled with a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state with a bulk modulus [K = 1/b = -V(∂P/∂V)] of 12.9(7) GPa. This is comparable with other framework materials such as ZIF-8 and Zn(CN)2. Pressurization between 0.68 and 0.87 GPa produces a more pronounced but continuous (second-order transition) shift in the diffraction peaks (ΔV = 8.2%). This compressibility is consistent with a pressure-induced SCO event (HS to LS). Above 0.87 GPa, the iron(II) sites are in the LS state and normal pressure-induced compression is evident. The bulk modulus of this region [K = 58(1) GPa] is also modeled with a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state. Thus, the LS material is less compressible than the HS material at ambient pressure. It is often the case that the high-pressure phases are less compressible.

elements.content: The thermal dependence of χM T investigated at 0.15, 0.27, 0.39, 0.42, 0.52, and 0.68 GPa is displayed in . At 0.15 GPa, a very incomplete HS → LS state conversion occurs involving ca. 10% of the iron­(II) centers (T 1/2 ∼ 98 K). A slight pressure increase (0.27 GPa) results in an additional 24% HS → LS state conversion, with the spin transition remaining gradual (T 1/2 ∼ 141 K). Despite that a fairly gradual conversion thermal hysteresis is present (T 1/2↓ ∼ 137 K and T 1/2↑ ∼ 146 K). At 0.39 GPa, approximately 50% of the iron­(II) centers undergo a cooperative spin conversion characterized by a less symmetric hysteresis (T 1/2 ∼ 195 K). At 0.42 GPa, a subtle two-step SCO behavior is observed. At this pressure, the HS → LS conversion progresses a further 17% and thermal hysteresis widens (T 1/2↓ ∼ 206 K and T 1/2↑ ∼ 218 K). At 0.52 and 0.68 GPa, the spin transition is practically complete and the two-step behavior is more distinct. The overall SCO character remains the same at these pressures, but the transition temperatures increase with pressure (T 1/2↓ ∼ 228 K and T 1/2↑ ∼ 241 K and T 1/2↓ ∼ 245K and T 1/2↑ ∼ 257 K for 0.52 and 0.68 GPa, respectively). Most importantly, a two-step SCO is revealed for A·2H 2 O under the enticement of hydrostatic pressure, confirming our general synthetic platform for the purposeful generation of multistep SCO transitions. The presence of a one-step SCO in the dehydrated species indicates that the ligand···H2O interaction is imperative for such multistep behavior. We suggest that removal of this interaction provides a less favorable array of ferro- and antiferroelastic pathways for the stabilization of fractional HS/LS states, and thus an abrupt transition between 100% HS and LS states occurs.

elements.content: In the mean-field theory of phase transitions, the pressure dependence T 1/2(p) follows the Clapeyron relationship T 1 / 2 ( p ) = T 1 / 2 + p ( Δ V / Δ S ) where ΔV/ΔS = ∂T 1/2(p)/∂p represents the average pressure dependence of T 1/2(p) and ΔV and ΔS are respectively the change of the volume and entropy per mole of compound upon the spin transition. A linear fitting of the experimental T 1/2 av(p) versus p plot (Figure S12) gives a straight line (R = 0.97) characterized by a slope of 302 K/GPa. It is worth noting that extrapolation of T 1/2 av(p) at 0.9 GPa gives a value of ca. 340 K, which is consistent with the expected spin transition observed at room temperature via powder X-ray diffraction (). Using ΔV [≈50 Å3 per iron­(II)] and ΔS (∼88 J K mol–1) values for A, which has a structure similar to that of A·2H 2 O, a slope of 342 K/GPa is obtained for A·2H 2 O. This value compares well with that obtained for the linear fitting of A·2H 2 O and several related coordination polymers. However, it is markedly larger than those found for several mononuclear compounds and 2D coordination polymers, suggesting that the differences in the slope of the Clapeyron relationship are most likely related to the relatively rigid nature of this SCO lattice.

A linear fitting of the experimental T 1/2 av(p) versus p plot (Figure S12) gives a straight line (R = 0.97) characterized by a slope of 302 K/GPa. It is worth noting that extrapolation of T 1/2 av(p) at 0.9 GPa gives a value of ca. 340 K, which is consistent with the expected spin transition observed at room temperature via powder X-ray diffraction (). Using ΔV [~50 Å3 per iron(II)] and ΔS (~88 J K mol-1) values for A, which has a structure similar to that of A⋅2H  2  O, a slope of 342 K/GPa is obtained for A⋅2H  2  O. This value compares well with that obtained for the linear fitting of A⋅2H  2  O and several related coordination polymers. However, it is markedly larger than those found for several mononuclear compounds and 2D coordination polymers, suggesting that the differences in the slope of the Clapeyron relationship are most likely related to the relatively rigid nature of this SCO lattice.

elements.content: With the application of pressure, the zero-point energy difference, ΔE = E HS – E LS, between the HS and LS states increases, resulting in a more readily accessible pathway between their respective energy wells upon cooling. Consequently, higher transition temperatures result from increasing pressure. Pressure also affects the SCO nature because of its effect on the intra- and intermolecular interactions in the solid state. For most SCO materials, increasing pressure reduces the number of HS centers at high temperatures and additionally decreases the hysteresis width and the slope of the transition curve. However, for some SCO compounds, the pressure does not negatively affect the cooperative behavior because the SCO regime remains essentially unaltered in a moderate range of pressures. Here, we find an interesting case where increasing the pressure produces a greater extent of HS-to-LS conversion and higher transition temperatures but, unusually, also results in more effective cooperativity (i.e., wider hysteresis loop widths and more abrupt spin transitions). With external stimuli under mild pressure applications (i.e., <0.42 GPa), it is conceivable that the host and guest contents could accommodate a fractional conversion to the LS state because the guests do not occupy all of the void volume. However, in order to accommodate a greater extent of HS-to-LS conversion, the Hofmann layers must distort, as is reflected in the multistep spin transition curves at pressures above 0.42 GPa. At these pressures, it must also be considered whether some of the guest molecules may be expelled; however, upon pressure release, SCO inactivation is immediately reestablished, suggesting that this is not the case. The increase in the cooperativity with pressure indicates a strengthening of the interactions, such as hydrogen bonding and π–π stacking, with pressure and reflects the cooperativity in the thermal spin transition of A. Overall, the thermal- and pressure-induced magnetic behaviors of A·2H 2 O compared to A suggest that the cooperativity is intrinsic to this overall lattice topology and that steric effects hinder the spin transition when guest molecules are present. The effect of pressure on the desolvated phase, A, would be interesting to compare but is not possible at this point because of the difficulties in loading a fully dehydrated material in the pressure cell.

elements.content: In summary, we report a new 2D Hofmann-type material incorporating a functionalized 1,2,4-triazole ligand and confirm that this general synthetic approach is broadly viable for generating multistep spin transitions. By this methodology, the combination of multiple interaction sites generated by the unique ligand design in parallel with the Hofmann topology, which is capable of stabilizing lattice distortions, aims to produce an optimal array of ferro- and antiferroelastic pathways for multistep SCO to occur. We find in [FeIIPd­(CN)4(thiome)2]·2H2O when the guest molecules are present in the lattice, a HS-to-LS transition of the iron­(II) sites embedded in the Hofmann layer is inhibited. The appearance of a spin transition with removal of the internal guest pressure via dehydration evidences a guest “blocking” argument. Alongside this, the guest-blocking mechanism is further supported by the presence of a spin transition in the hydrated phase under mild hydrostatic pressure. The presence of a two-step SCO in the hydrated species under applied pressure but a one-step SCO in the dehydrated species indicates that the ligand···H2O interaction is intrinsic to the multistep SCO process. We attribute this distinction to a subtle variation in the ferro- and antiferroelastic pathways with removal of the lattice guests alongside a more flexible lattice in the apohost (i.e., vacant void space where, for example, ligand rotation may occur). Together, these variations would not stabilize the structural distortions and less favorable lattice geometry requisite of mixed HS and LS states in multistep transitions but oblige the iron­(II) sites to proceed rapidly from HS to LS. We note that the presence of a two-step transition under hydrostatic pressure does not in itself confirm that this general approach is broadly applicable for generating multistep transitions because it is fairly common for such environments to induce structural distortions but will be comprehensively confirmed by examination of further examples in this series in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we report a new 2D Hofmann-type material incorporating a functionalized 1,2,4-triazole ligand and confirm that this general synthetic approach is broadly viable for generating multistep spin transitions. By this methodology, the combination of multiple interaction sites generated by the unique ligand design in parallel with the Hofmann topology, which is capable of stabilizing lattice distortions, aims to produce an optimal array of ferro- and antiferroelastic pathways for multistep SCO to occur. We find in [FeIIPd(CN)4(thiome)2]⋅2H2O when the guest molecules are present in the lattice, a HS-to-LS transition of the iron(II) sites embedded in the Hofmann layer is inhibited. The appearance of a spin transition with removal of the internal guest pressure via dehydration evidences a guest "blocking" argument. Alongside this, the guest-blocking mechanism is further supported by the presence of a spin transition in the hydrated phase under mild hydrostatic pressure. The presence of a two-step SCO in the hydrated species under applied pressure but a one-step SCO in the dehydrated species indicates that the ligand⋅⋅⋅H2O interaction is intrinsic to the multistep SCO process. We attribute this distinction to a subtle variation in the ferro- and antiferroelastic pathways with removal of the lattice guests alongside a more flexible lattice in the apohost (i.e., vacant void space where, for example, ligand rotation may occur). Together, these variations would not stabilize the structural distortions and less favorable lattice geometry requisite of mixed HS and LS states in multistep transitions but oblige the iron(II) sites to proceed rapidly from HS to LS. We note that the presence of a two-step transition under hydrostatic pressure does not in itself confirm that this general approach is broadly applicable for generating multistep transitions because it is fairly common for such environments to induce structural distortions but will be comprehensively confirmed by examination of further examples in this series in the future.

elements.content: This material presents the first comprehensive thermal- and pressure-induced SCO investigation into the consequence of volumetric host lattice contraction whereby guest molecules inhibit contraction of the host lattice. This study opens avenues for exploiting the geometric contraction of spin-state variation in parallel with lattice topology to a tailor guest fit and produces novel SCO properties that are “hidden” at ambient pressures. This investigation also indicates that guest manipulation may be a feasible new approach for tuning multistep spin transitions such as the number of steps. We are currently pursuing such studies on an analogous system in this series.

We are currently pursuing such studies on an analogous system in this series.

cln_elements.content:
All reagents were commercially available and were used as received [iron­(II) perchlorate was handled carefully and in small amounts to avoid any potential explosions].

Ligand Synthesis

4-Amino-1,2,4-triazole (1.5 g, 17.5 mmol) and 5-methyl-2-thiophenecarboxaldehyde (2.76 g, 21.9 mmol) were dissolved in 50 mL of ethanol (EtOH) along with 4 drops of concentrated H2SO4. The solution was refluxed and stirred for 5 h. With cooling to room temperature, a white precipitate formed and was washed with cold water (H2O) followed by EtOH. The crude product was recrystallized from EtOH. M w: 192.25. Yield: 1.7 g (51%). 1H NMR (200 MHz, DMSO-d 6, δ/ppm): 9.15 (s, 1H), 9.09 (s, 2H), 7.51 (d, 3 J HH = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 6.98 (d, 3 J HH = 3.6 Hz, 1H), 2.53 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d 6, δ/ppm): 152.8, 146.9, 138.8, 136.0, 133.9, 127.3, 15.5. ESI-MS: m/z 192.87 (M + H peak), 214.87 (M + Na peak). IR (solid, ν/cm–1): 3108 (s), 2960 (m), 1601 (s), 1508 (s), 1490 (s), 1475 (s), 1452 (m), 1379 (m), 1295 (m), 1247 (m), 1220 (m), 1205 (m), 1164 (s), 1058 (s), 1048 (s), 975 (m), 838 (m), 806 (s), 621 (m), 573 (s), 545 (m), 518 (m), 485 (m). Microanalysis. Calcd for C8H8N4S: C, 49.98; H, 4.19; N, 29.15. Found: C, 49.94; H, 4.24; N, 29.21.

cln_elements.content: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements on a bulk crystalline sample of A reveal the emergence of an abrupt and hysteretic one-step SCO (). With cooling from 300 K, the χM T values remain constant at 3.4 cm K mol–1, consistent with HS iron­(II) sites until 185 K, where there is an abrupt drop in the χM T values to 0.2 cm K mol–1 indicative of LS iron­(II) sites. Below 165 K, the χM T values remain constant at 0.2 cm K mol–1. With heating, the same one-step behavior is observed with a hysteresis loop of 20 K (T 1/2↓ = 184 K; T 1/2↑ = 204 K). A DSC measurement was also carried out on A in the 120–300 K temperature range, and the critical temperatures obtained from the exothermic (T 1/2↓ = 183 K) and endothermic (T 1/2↑ = 206 K) curves are in good agreement with the magnetic data (Figure S6).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Dehydrated (A) Magnetic Properties and Structure

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements on a bulk crystalline sample of A reveal the emergence of an abrupt and hysteretic one-step SCO (). With cooling from 300 K, the χM T values remain constant at 3.4 cm K mol-1, consistent with HS iron(II) sites until 185 K, where there is an abrupt drop in the χM T values to 0.2 cm K mol-1 indicative of LS iron(II) sites. Below 165 K, the χM T values remain constant at 0.2 cm K mol-1. With heating, the same one-step behavior is observed with a hysteresis loop of 20 K (T 1/2↓ = 184 K; T 1/2↑ = 204 K). A DSC measurement was also carried out on A in the 120-300 K temperature range, and the critical temperatures obtained from the exothermic (T 1/2↓ = 183 K) and endothermic (T 1/2↑ = 206 K) curves are in good agreement with the magnetic data (Figure S6).
